\begin{document}

\title{Problem Set 1 Solutions}


\author{Tyler Ransom}

\maketitle
Directions: Answer all questions. Clearly label all answers. Show
all of your code. Compute standard errors for all parameter estimates.
Turn in the following to me via your dropbox (in a folder labeled
'MatlabPS2.1') in Sakai by 11:59 p.m. on Thursday, July 26, 2012: 
\begin{itemize}
\item m-file(s)
\item a log file (from off the cluster)
\item matsub.oXXXXX file
\item pdf version of your writeup with its \LaTeX source code
\end{itemize}
Put the names of all group members at the top of your writeup (each
student must turn in his/her own materials).
\begin{enumerate}
\item Multinomial Logit. 

\begin{enumerate}
\item See m-code
\item See results in Table 1. 
\item See results in Table 2. Coefficients and standard errors are the same
to two decimal places
\item $\beta_{5j}$ is the effect of an additional year of schooling on
the probability of choosing choice $j$ (in relation to the base choice,
{}``other'').
\end{enumerate}
\item Unobserved heterogeneity (Fixed and Random Effects). 

\begin{enumerate}
\item See Table 3.
\item See Table 3. The coefficients on male, hgc and BA all go down a little
bit when including the full set of regressors. The coefficients on
experience, Diploma, and AA (and the constant) all go up. This relates
to unobserved heterogeneity because AFQT and mother's education are
time-invariant unobservables which are correlated with the other covariantes
(e.g. own education). This exercise was meant to approximate for unobserved
heterogeneity by treating some time invariant regressors as unobservables.
\item See Table 4. Examples of variables in the error term in (a) and (b)
but not (c) {[}and which are correlated with the regressors{]} are:
father's education, family income at age 12, and innate ability. Each
of these variables is time-invariant, and so is differenced out by
the fixed effect estimator.
\item See Table 5. \texttt{male} goes down with RE; \texttt{AFQT} goes down
with RE; \texttt{Mhgc} stays the same; \texttt{hgc} goes up with both
FE and RE; \texttt{exper} stays pretty much the same; \texttt{Diploma}
goes up with FE and down with RE; \texttt{AA} goes down with FE and
RE; \texttt{BA} goes up with FE and RE. As you can see, there is no
hard-and-fast rule for how coefficients change when unobserved heterogeneity
is corrected for. The estimates also are sensitive to the assumptions
about the structure of the unobserved heterogeneity.
\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
\pagebreak{}

\begin{table}


\caption{Multinomial Logit Coefficients (\texttt{fminunc})}


\bigskip{}


\centering{}%
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
\hline 
 & \multicolumn{2}{c}{Coefficients} & \multicolumn{2}{c}{Standard Errors}\tabularnewline
 & (school) & (work) & (school) & (work)\tabularnewline
\hline 
constant & -3.437 & -0.444 & 0.362 & 0.165\tabularnewline
male & 0.344 & 0.222 & 0.072 & 0.032\tabularnewline
AFQT & -0.237 & -0.208 & 0.043 & 0.019\tabularnewline
Mhgc & 0.038 & -0.012 & 0.014 & 0.006\tabularnewline
hgc & 0.017 & -0.177 & 0.026 & 0.013\tabularnewline
exper & -0.417 & 1.034 & 0.042 & 0.013\tabularnewline
Diploma & 0.332 & 1.016 & 0.137 & 0.053\tabularnewline
AA & -0.283 & 0.736 & 0.191 & 0.071\tabularnewline
BA & -0.032 & 2.252 & 0.156 & 0.061\tabularnewline
\hline 
log likelihood & \multicolumn{4}{c}{-3,877.14}\tabularnewline
$N\times T$ & \multicolumn{4}{c}{32,370}\tabularnewline
\hline 
\end{tabular}
\end{table}
